captions.text:
Sheriffs throughout the country are starting
to get desperate when it comes to issue of

marijuana legalization look a big part of
their jobs is locking people for possession

or marijuana trafficking so they want to keep
it illegal as a result about ten sheriffs

from three different states in U.S. have filed
lawsuits against the state of Colorado for

legalizing marijuana for recreation use according
to the associated press the sheriffs from

Colorado Kansas and Nebraska say that Colorado's
2012 marijuana legalization vote violates

federal law and should not be permitted in
fact one is one sheriff is quoted as saying

a state may not establish its own policy that
is directly counter to federal policy against

trafficking in controlled substance they're
getting desperate OK now keep in mind that

in every state that has legalized for recreation
use they've done it through ballet initiatives

the people of the state have spoken they want
to legal it for not only medicinal but recreational

use but these sheriffs don't care whenever
you hear about conservatives who are in favor

of state's right they only want state's rights
when it's convenient for them but when it

comes to issues like this oh well you know
there's profit motive there there are people

that are making money through prohibition
so who cares what people want yeah I the thing

that bothers me the most is a understand that
there are going to be some sheriffs that look

the law changes the sheriff is still the same
guy he was and he might be super old school

he might have grown up in a time when weed
was thought of as like the worst drug you

could possibly take but it's not like we're
like thinking well what would happen if we

were to legalize marijuana we know now we
know that crime rates in Colorado are down

the revenue is up youth marijuana use is down
if that doesn't change your view then your

view is meaningless it's not based on anything
in reality like that should lead to want to

do it in your own state for the revenue if
for nothing else and it looks like it could

actually help out the young people in your
state but John that's the whole definition

of a conservative that you do not want change
you want to keep things exactly as they are

that is why you're a conservative so facts
are not relevant it's about your feelings

it's about your sense of identity and so this
is what I'm used to I refer madness pot is

dangerous it's always been dangerous and I
don't want to change it and facts are not

pertinent to this issue now on legal grounds
it is an interesting case it is I mean they'll

have to sort this out and that's been the
conundrum the whole time can we have state

law and federal law that contradict one another
I think they're going to fight a losing battle

here eventually I think almost all the states
at some point will go towards legalizing because

they have seen that revenue's up I think you're
both right I think that it's part of the reason

that they're against it is because of they've
always been against it and part of the reason

is yeah revenue might be up for state yeah
but it's not up for the cops who love to the

seizures and now you can't seize somebody's
car you know in Colorado not likely to seize

their yacht but that's happened in other jurisdictions
right their revenue is down and they don't

like it no but Ana made a really good point
about that they only like it when it's convenient

for them so there's a lot of state laws that
you know don't follow federal law like same

sex in Alabama prostitution in Nevada gun
laws in Texas but it's OK when it's good for

them yeah that's a good point and also like
I agree with you that I think that a lot of

them at least the leadership in the police
departments is going to care a lot about that

revenue I mean the people don't on the street
they're going to feel pressure I don't think

they personally really care about the revenues
aside from the pressure put on them but we

also saw about a year into the legalization
the recreational legalization in Colorado

there were interviews with a number of cops
being asked like how has this changed your

job and they just say yeah you know what I
didn't like giving out those citations for

like teens using pot anyway in a lot of places
they don't often maybe if they're black but

if they're white they don't give them the
citation anyway so it doesn't actually change

their day to day job all that much except
for possibly changing how much money they
are bringing in

title: Sheriffs Are Suing Colorado For Having Legal Weed
